author: Edwin Meza
title: Pemex confirma derrame en Tabasco tras fuga en ducto; hay playas negras y muerte de fauna
text:
Pemex confirma derrame en Tabasco tras fuga en ducto; hay playas negras y muerte de fauna
Tras un derrame, Petr√≥leos Mexicanos (Pemex) atendi√≥ dos fugas en un ducto submarino que transporta aceite crudo desde la Plataforma Akal-C hasta la Terminal Mar√≠tima de Dos Bocas, en Para√≠so, Tabasco.
Las autoridades reportaron afectaciones a la fauna y contaminaci√≥n en las playas, lo que oblig√≥ a cerrar los accesos en algunas de ellas debido al riesgo por este desastre ambiental.
Pemex detecta fuga y derrame en la costa
Tras detectar el incidente, Pemex instal√≥ dos abrazaderas met√°licas para contener la fuga. Actualmente, se preparan las maniobras para verificar la hermeticidad del ducto y reanudar su operaci√≥n.
Sin embargo, parte del aceite se desplaz√≥ hasta la costa de la TMDB, abarcando una extensi√≥n de 7 kil√≥metros, inform√≥ la empresa productiva del estado.
Limpieza y di√°logo con pescadores
Pemex activ√≥ de inmediato a personal y equipo especializado para llevar a cabo labores de limpieza, las cuales se prev√© concluyan en las pr√≥ximas horas.
Adem√°s, se inici√≥ di√°logo con comunidades de pescadores de la zona para establecer medidas de prevenci√≥n y reactivar su actividad productiva.
La petrolera notific√≥ el evento a la Agencia de Seguridad, Energ√≠a y Ambiente (ASEA), de la Secretar√≠a de Medio Ambiente y Recursos Naturales (Semarnat), para que se implementen las acciones de remediaci√≥n correspondientes.
Muerte de fauna y playas negras por derrame de Pemex
Los habitantes y pescadores reportaron la muerte de fauna y afectaciones ambientales debido al derrame de crudo en las aguas del Golfo de M√©xico. La agencia de fotograf√≠a Cuartoscuro constat√≥ los hechos.
En la localidad Playita El Mirador, seg√∫n medios locales, la poblaci√≥n se quej√≥ de la cancelaci√≥n de servicios tur√≠sticos durante el fin de semana largo, debido a la presencia de chapopote y aceite en el mar.
El ayuntamiento de Para√≠so, encabezado por el alcalde Alfonso Baca Sevilla, iz√≥ la bandera negra como se√±al de que la zona no es apta para el turismo ni la pesca.

author: www.yunnan.cn,‰∫ëÂçóÊó•Êä•Êä•‰∏öÈõÜÂõ¢,‰∫ëÂçóÁΩë
title: ÁΩëÁªúÂøÉÁêÜËØäÁñóÁ©∂Á´ü"Âä©Â®É"ËøòÊòØ"ÂùëÂ®É"Ôºü_Á§æ‰ºöÁÉ≠ÁÇπ_Á§æ‰ºöÈ¢ëÈÅì_‰∫ëÂçóÁΩë
text:
ÂéüÊ†áÈ¢òÔºöÁΩëÁªúÂøÉÁêÜËØäÁñóÁ©∂Á´ü‚ÄúÂä©Â®É‚ÄùËøòÊòØ‚ÄúÂùëÂ®É‚ÄùÔºü
ËøëÂπ¥Êù•ÔºåÂú®ÁΩëÁªúÁõ¥Êí≠Èó¥„ÄÅÁü≠ËßÜÈ¢ëÂπ≥Âè∞‰∏äÔºå‰∏Ä‰∫õ‰∏ªÊí≠Ëá™Áß∞‚ÄúÂøÉÁêÜÂí®ËØ¢Â∏à‚Äù‚ÄúÂÆ∂Â∫≠ÊïôËÇ≤Â∏à‚ÄùÁ≠âÔºåÂÆ£Áß∞ÂèØ‰ª•‚ÄúËß£ÂÜ≥ÂÑøÁ´•ÈùíÂ∞ëÂπ¥ÂøÉÁêÜÈóÆÈ¢ò‚Äù„ÄÇ
ËøôÊ†∑ÁöÑÁΩëÁªúÂøÉÁêÜËØäÁñóÔºåÂú®‰∏ì‰∏öÁöÑÂøÉÁêÜÂåªÁîüÁúãÊù•ÔºåÊòØÂ∞ÜÂåªÂ≠¶ËØäÁñóËøáÁ®ãÁªùÂØπÂåñ„ÄÅÁÆÄÂçïÂåñÔºåÂÆπÊòìÂºïÂèëÂÆ∂ÈïøÂá∫Áé∞Ëá™ÊàëÂê¶ÂÆö„ÄÅÁÑ¶ËôëÊÅêÊÉßÁ≠âÊÉÖÁª™Ôºå‰∫ßÁîü‰∏çÂøÖË¶ÅÁöÑÂøÉÁêÜË¥üÊãÖ„ÄÇ
‰∏ÄËà¨ËÄåË®ÄÔºåÂøÉÁêÜÁñæÁóÖÈ°ªÁî±ÂÖ∑ÊúâÊâß‰∏öËµÑÊ†ºÁöÑ‰∏ì‰∏ö‰∫∫ÂëòÊ†πÊçÆËØäÊñ≠Ê†áÂáÜËøõË°åÂà§Êñ≠ÔºåÂåªÁîüË¶ÅÁªºÂêàËÄÉÈáèÁóáÁä∂ÁöÑ‰∏•ÈáçÁ®ãÂ∫¶„ÄÅÊåÅÁª≠Êó∂Èó¥„ÄÅÊó¢ÂæÄÂè≤„ÄÅÂà∫ÊøÄÂõ†Á¥†Á≠âÔºåËøòË¶Å‰∏éÂÖ∂‰ªñÁñæÁóÖËøõË°åËæ®Âà´ÔºåËøôÊó¢Ë¶ÅÊ±Ç‰∏ì‰∏öÁü•ËØÜÔºå‰πüÈúÄË¶Å‰∏¥Â∫äÁªèÈ™å„ÄÇ
ÈöèÁùÄÁßëÊôÆ‰∏éÂÆ£‰º†ÁöÑÊ∑±ÂÖ•ÔºåÂÑøÁ´•ÈùíÂ∞ëÂπ¥ÂøÉÁêÜÈóÆÈ¢òÊó•ÁõäÂèóÂà∞ÈáçËßÜ„ÄÇÁÑ∂ËÄåÔºåÂØπ‰∫éËÆ∏Â§ö‰∏çÂÖ∑Â§á‰∏ì‰∏öÁü•ËØÜÁöÑÂÆ∂ÈïøËÄåË®ÄÔºåÂÆπÊòìÂØπÁΩëÁªú‰∏ä‰∏Ä‰∫õËØ¥Ê≥ï‰ø°‰ª•‰∏∫ÁúüÔºåÊ≠§Á±ªÁõ¥Êí≠Èó¥ÂíåÁü≠ËßÜÈ¢ëËØÑËÆ∫Âå∫‰∏ç‰πèÂÆ∂ÈïøÁöÑÊ±ÇÂä©ÁïôË®Ä„ÄÇ
ÂÆãÂ•≥Â£´ËØ¥ÔºåÂ•πÁöÑÂ•≥ÂÑø‰∏éÂêåÈæÑ‰∫∫Áõ∏ÊØîËæÉ‰∏∫ÂÜÖÂêëÔºå‰∏çÁà±ËØ¥ËØùÔºå‰∏çÁà±‰∫§ÊúãÂèãÔºåÈÅáÂà∞Êå´ÊäòÂÆπÊòìËæÉÈïøÊó∂Èó¥Èô∑Âú®ÊÇ≤‰º§ÊÉÖÁª™‰∏≠„ÄÇÂÆ∂‰∫∫‰∏∫Ê≠§ÊÑüÂà∞ÊãÖÂøÉÔºå‰∫éÊòØÂ•πÂú®Âà∑Âà∞Âá†‰ΩçÂøÉÁêÜÂçö‰∏ªÁöÑÁõ¥Êí≠Èó¥ÂíåËßÜÈ¢ëÂêéÔºåË¥≠‰π∞‰∫Ü‚ÄúÂøÉÁêÜËÆ≠ÁªÉËØæÁ®ã‚ÄùÂíå‚ÄúÂøÉÁêÜËÆ≠ÁªÉËê•‚ÄùÈ°πÁõÆ„ÄÇ
ÂÉèÂÆãÂ•≥Â£´‰∏ÄÊ†∑ÁöÑÊÉÖÂÜµÂπ∂‰∏çÈ≤úËßÅ„ÄÇËÆ∞ËÄÖË∞ÉÊü•ÂèëÁé∞Ôºå‰∏Ä‰∫õ‚ÄúÁΩëÁªúÂøÉÁêÜËØäÁñó‚ÄùÁöÑËßÜÈ¢ëÂíåÁõ¥Êí≠ÔºåÂÖà‰ª•ADHDÔºàÊ≥®ÊÑèÁº∫Èô∑‰∏éÂ§öÂä®ÈöúÁ¢çÔºâ„ÄÅÊäëÈÉÅ„ÄÅÁÑ¶Ëôë„ÄÅÂéåÂ≠¶Á≠âÁÉ≠Èó®ËØùÈ¢òÂê∏ÂºïÂÖ≥Ê≥®ÔºåÈÄöËøá‰∏ÄÁ≥ªÂàóÁöÑËØùÊúØÊøÄËµ∑ÈúÄÊ±ÇÂêéÔºåÂÜçÊé®ÈîÄËØæÁ®ã„ÄÅ‰øùÂÅ•ÂìÅ„ÄÅ‰∏ÄÂØπ‰∏ÄÂí®ËØ¢ËæÖÂØºÁ≠âÊî∂Ë¥πÈ°πÁõÆÔºåÁîöËá≥ÂΩ¢ÊàêËæÉ‰∏∫ÂÆåÊï¥ÁöÑÈìæÊù°„ÄÇËÆ∏Â§öÁõ¥Êí≠Èó¥ÈÉΩÊúâÈùûÂ∏∏ÊòéÊòæÁöÑ‚ÄúÂä†ÂæÆ‰ø°ÊàñÁæ§ËÅä‚ÄùÁ≠âÊ†áËØÜÔºå‰∏ªÊí≠‰πü‰∏çÊñ≠ÈáçÂ§ç‚ÄúÂÖàÁÇπÂÖ≥Ê≥®ÔºåÂä†‰∏ä‰∫íÂä©Áæ§‚ÄùÔºåÂú®‰∏Ä‰∫õÁü≠ËßÜÈ¢ëÁöÑËØÑËÆ∫Âå∫ÔºåÂçö‰∏ªÂõûÂ§çÁßÅ‰ø°‰πüÂú®‰∏çÊñ≠ÂºïÂØºÊèêÈóÆÁöÑÁΩëÂèã‚ÄúÂä†ÁßÅ‰ø°‚Äù„ÄÇ
ÁΩëÁªú‰∏ä‚ÄúËÆ≠ÁªÉËê•‚Äù‚Äú‰ΩìÈ™åËê•‚Äù‚ÄúÊàêÈïøËê•‚ÄùÁ≠âËØæÁ®ã‰∫ßÂìÅÔºå‰ª∑Ê†º‰ªéÂçÅÂá†ÂÖÉËá≥Âá†ÂçÅÂÖÉ‰∏çÁ≠âÔºåÈîÄÈáèÂ§öÁöÑËææÂá†Áôæ‰∏äÂçÉÂçï„ÄÇÊúâÁöÑÁõ¥Êí≠Èó¥ÂîÆÂçñËØæÁ®ãÊ†áÊ¶ú‚ÄúÂêçÂ∏à‚ÄùÔºå‰ª∑Ê†º‰ªé299ÂÖÉÂà∞599ÂÖÉ‰∏çÁ≠âÔºåÈîÄÈáè‰∏ç‰Ωé„ÄÇ
ÂèóËÆø‰∏ìÂÆ∂Ë°®Á§∫Ôºå‰∏ì‰∏öÁöÑÂøÉÁêÜÁßëÊôÆËßÜÈ¢ëÁ°ÆÂÆûËÉΩ‰∏∫ÂÆ∂ÈïøÊèê‰æõÂÆ∂Â∫≠ÊïôËÇ≤ÁöÑÂèÇËÄÉÔºå‰ΩÜ‰∏Ä‰∫õ‰ª•Ëê•Âà©‰∏∫‰∏ªË¶ÅÁõÆÊ†áÁöÑËßÜÈ¢ë‰∏•ÈáçÁº∫‰πè‰∏ì‰∏öÊÄßÔºå‰∏ç‰ªÖËµ∑‰∏çÂà∞ÁßëÊôÆ‰ΩúÁî®ÔºåÂèçËÄå‰ºö‰∫ßÁîüËØØÂØºÔºåÁîöËá≥ÈÄ†ÊàêÊõ¥‰∏•ÈáçÁöÑ‰∏çËâØÂêéÊûú„ÄÇËøôÊ†∑ÁöÑ‚Äú‰π±ÊäïÂåª‚ÄùË°å‰∏∫ÊΩúËóèÈ£éÈô©ÔºåËΩªËÄÖ‚ÄúÊ≤ªÁñó‚ÄùÂêéÊú™ËßÅÊîπÂñÑÔºå‰∏•ÈáçËÄÖÂèØËÉΩËÆ©Êú¨Ë∫´Â≠òÂú®ÈóÆÈ¢òÁöÑÂ≠©Â≠êÁóáÁä∂Âä†ÈáçÔºåÁîöËá≥ÂØºËá¥ÂøÉÁêÜÁñæÁóÖÂêëÊõ¥Ê∑±Á®ãÂ∫¶ÂèëÂ±ï„ÄÇ
ÁªèËøáÂ§öÂπ¥Êù•ÁöÑÂèëÂ±ïÔºåÂΩìÂâçÊàëÂõΩÁ≤æÁ•ûÂøÉÁêÜÊúçÂä°Ê†∑Âºè‰∏∞ÂØåÂ§öÂÖÉÔºåÂÖ®ÂõΩÁªü‰∏ÄÂøÉÁêÜÊè¥Âä©ÁÉ≠Á∫ø12356‰πüÂ∑≤ÂºÄÈÄö„ÄÇÊ≠§Â§ñÔºåÊ±üËãèÁ≠âÂú∞Â∑≤Â∞ÜÈÉ®ÂàÜÂøÉÁêÜÊ≤ªÁñóÈ°πÁõÆÁ∫≥ÂÖ•Âåª‰øùÊîØ‰ªòËåÉÂõ¥„ÄÇÂèóËÆø‰∫∫Â£´Ë°®Á§∫ÔºåÁ∫≥ÂÖ•Âåª‰øùÂêéÔºåÊõ¥Â§ö‰∫∫ÂºÄÂßãÁü•ÈÅìÂøÉÁêÜÊ≤ªÁñóÔºå‰πüÊúâÊù°‰ª∂Êé•ÂèóÁõ∏ÂÖ≥Ê≤ªÁñóÊúçÂä°ÔºåÊúâÂä©‰∫é‰∏ì‰∏öËØäÊñ≠ÊúçÂä°Ëµ∞ËøõÂçÉÂÆ∂‰∏áÊà∑„ÄÇÂ∞ΩÁÆ°Â¶ÇÊ≠§ÔºåÂú®Êó∫ÁõõÁöÑÈúÄÊ±Ç‰πã‰∏ãÔºå‰∏ì‰∏ö‰∫∫ÊâçÁü≠Áº∫„ÄÅËé∑ÂèñÊ∏†ÈÅìÁº∫Â§±Á≠âÊÉÖÂÜµ‰æùÁÑ∂Â≠òÂú®Ôºå‚ÄúÊúâÂøÉÂïÜÂÆ∂‚Äù‰æøÁõØ‰∏äÂÆ∂ÈïøÁöÑÁÑ¶ËôëÔºå‰ª•Ê≠§ÁâüÂà©„ÄÇ
ÂèóËÆø‰∏ìÂÆ∂ÂëºÂêÅÔºåÂÖ¨‰ºóË¶ÅÂ¢ûÂº∫‰ø°ÊÅØÁ≠õÈÄâÂíåËæ®Âà´ËÉΩÂäõÔºå‰ªéÊ≠£ËßÑÊ∏†ÈÅìÂ≠¶‰π†„ÄÅ‰∫ÜËß£Áõ∏ÂÖ≥Áü•ËØÜÔºåÂêë‰∏ì‰∏öÁöÑÁ≤æÁ•ûÂøÉÁêÜÊú∫ÊûÑ„ÄÅÂåªÈô¢Á≠âÂØªÊ±ÇÂ∏ÆÂä©ÂíåÊîØÊåÅÔºåÂØπÁΩëÁªú‰∏äÁöÑÁõ∏ÂÖ≥ËßÜÈ¢ëÂíå‰ø°ÊÅØ‰øùÊåÅÁêÜÊÄßÔºå‰∏çÁõ≤Âê¨Áõ≤‰ø°ËÉΩÊçÆÊ≠§‚ÄúÁ°ÆËØä‚ÄùÊàñ‚ÄúÁñóÊÑà‚Äù„ÄÇ‰∏éÊ≠§ÂêåÊó∂ÔºåÂ∫îËøõ‰∏ÄÊ≠•ÂÅ•ÂÖ®Á§æ‰ºöÂøÉÁêÜÊúçÂä°‰ΩìÁ≥ªÔºåÊâ©Â§ßÂøÉÁêÜÂÅ•Â∫∑ÊúçÂä°‰æõÁªôÔºåÊé¢Á¥¢‰ªéÁ§æÂå∫„ÄÅÂ≠¶Ê†°„ÄÅÁΩëÁªúÁ≠âÂ§öÊ∏†ÈÅìÊê≠Âª∫‰∏ì‰∏öÁßëÊôÆÂπ≥Âè∞ÔºåÂπ∂ÊåÅÁª≠Âä†Âº∫ÂØπÂøÉÁêÜÂí®ËØ¢„ÄÅÁ≤æÁ•ûÂç´ÁîüÁ≠â‰∏ì‰∏ö‰∫∫ÊâçÁöÑÂüπÂÖªÂíåÂüπËÆ≠ÂäõÂ∫¶„ÄÇ

author: HaloRock‚Ñ¢
title: ADL trained ZOG Bots
text:
We appreciate you giving us some of your valuable time, & daring to search for uncensored information about this clown world & the many crimes & conspiracies perpetrated by the parasitic ruling class against humanity. We will continue to do our best to deliver you factual, useful information & some entertainment on a daily basis, though we generally don‚Äôt report on politics, because it is irrelevant in the grand scheme of things. It's just an illusion they use to divide & confuse us. Unfortunately, there is no political solution, they have made sure of that.

author: Kendall Nelson, Tim Burke and Matthew Oliver
title: The University Partnership Program Jumps into OpenStack Swift
text: Students from the Doha campus at Carnegie Mellon University participated in a university partnership program where they were mentored by OpenStack Swift contributors. The first time a UPP has focused on Swift! Mentor Matthew Oliver summarized his experiences with the students and co-mentor, Tim Burke. If you‚Äôre interested in more information about the University Partnership Program (UPP) reach out to [[email protected]](/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#9af9f5f7f7eff4f3eee3daf5eafff4f3f4fce8fbb4feffec) with your questions or check out the UPP website . OpenStack Swift isn‚Äôt a project that one can easily jump in and submit patches, well you can, but to be effective there is a level of onboarding that needs to take place first. And I‚Äôm very happy to say everyone did great, they all seemed to really start understanding the distributed and eventual consistent nature of Swift and all contributed to make some real changes to the Swift codebase. All the projects we set are real feature requests from the community, so not only are they making OpenStack Swift better, but they are helping real operators out in the world! Evolution of Communication I live in a very remote part of the world, well at least in our industry. And after many years working remotely for teams based all over the world, effective communication is a big topic for me. The students coming from the Qatar time zone may find similar issues as me so effective asynchronous communication is paramount. This was also evident in this summer internship project. I myself was in Australia, but had a better overlap with the students then Tim who is based on the west coast of the US. We managed to meet via OpenDev‚Äôs Meetpad (Jitsi) once a week and then other questions and guidance was via more asynchronous communication mechanisms as we got them established. Initially email, but as the students build up their dev environments and onboarded into the project also via Matrix/IRC and eventually into the code review system, Gerrit, itself. Some extra effective upstream learnings I tried to drive into them: - Transparency - push up code early, even if it isn‚Äôt ready. - We are all code-blind to our own code, and we need more eyes on it to keep up the quality and reduce bugs. But mostly to make the code even better! - Don‚Äôt be scared of how my code looks. Take the vanity out of it. - Do as much in the open as possible. In the project channel, email or code review system. - Reviewing code and asking questions in the code review system is a great way to learn about codebase and be a better dev. - push up code early, even if it isn‚Äôt ready. - Project first - Have a project first mindset, we‚Äôre all trying to make Swift better. - A -1 review in Gerrit isn‚Äôt a bad thing. Just means it isn‚Äôt ready to merge. Everyone gets -1‚Äôs, There are usually many patchsets before a change is ready to land. This is normal, it‚Äôs how we get great quality code. - Ask questions - It‚Äôs a big code base. There are no stupid questions and people are always happy to answer what something means, or why they did what they did. - Asking questions in code reviews of other devs via a +0 vote is great, especially if you want to know more about that particular area of the codebase. It‚Äôs how we‚Äôve all learnt. - Have fun - The community is a great bunch of people, and it should be fun. You have a dev environment you can easily reset. So go try patches out, break things, go have a blast. Onboarding As I already mentioned, Swift is a distributed system and there are a lot of moving parts. So having an understanding of all those parts is essential. So the first few weeks were devoted to onboarding and building up dev environments. I first started with a very high level of Swift, object storage in general, and meeting all the conceptual storage server types in the cluster and the flow of requests through the cluster. I‚Äôve been working on OpenTelemetry integration into Swift, so I could actually show live paths requests took through the cluster, which I think worked well. We talked about the WSGI framework and how one of the most important features of Swift is how easy it is to extend via WSGI middlewares. How many of Swift‚Äôs features are in middleware so operators can add their own code and/or turn off whatever they don‚Äôt want. From there we delved deeper into the Swift rings that are used by Sift components that allow Swift to scale without any central brain. Next the consistency engine behind the scenes that is checking and repairing objects on disk. Alongside the onboarding, everyone had a go of manually setting up a ‚ÄòSwift all in one‚Äô (SAIO) dev environment following the upstream docs. This allowed all the students to get a taste of Swift configuration and learn more about the components. Later they could just use the ‚Äòvagrant SAIO‚Äô (vSAIO) that all the devs use as it automates the process. A SAIO simulates a 4 node cluster and has helper scripts to reset your Swift environment, making a great sandbox for dev work, exploring and more fun‚Ä¶ breaking the system. As we went along the students also followed the upstream docs and started appearing on the Swift project IRC channel, using the Matrix to IRC bridge so they were permanently connected and aided in asynchronous communication with the upstream community. Projects The projects were real feature requests and I picked a bunch that seemed manageable, interesting and tended to follow the normal progression I see devs moving as they work on Swift. Starting out working on existing middleware in the proxy WSGI pipeline, moving to the consistency engine itself and starting to work on a new API whose starting point is an operator tool to start enabling a long awaited feature in Swift. The team surprised me and asked for more to choose from as they got the first one completed quickly and wanted to sink their teeth into more before moving to the harder ones. The original plan was for the team to work as a group to get the first few done, then split into smaller groups and each tackle a different project‚Ä¶but turns out we ran out of time. Although, I‚Äôd like to note I‚Äôve heard from multiple students that they plan to finish what they‚Äôve started and some are even interested in continuing to pick up some of the other projects I put forward! Add object-count quota for accounts in middleware There is an existing account quota middleware that provides soft quotas based on the number of bytes in an account. But there was a feature request to also provide a quota on the number of objects in an account too. This main use case for this as provided by the requester was due to filesystem inode limits. The entire team worked on this together. I know each had a go of writing tests and discussing how to implement it in the middleware. There was some good refactoring and this patch led to a deeper dive into Swift tests, the different types of tests (unit, function and probe) and how do you unit test in a distributed system that involves responses from other servers. This middleware is an older middleware in Swift and as such the API namespace we use is older. There have been discussions about modernising this to take advantage of the Swift sysmeta namespace. Currently this patch just extends the existing quota namespace to keep using the older meta namespace. And as Swift always tries to support backward compatibility, it would be better to migrate object-bytes quotas into the new namespace and only introduce object-count into the new namespace to reduce backwards compatibility code. This additional work was considered out of scope, and something we can come back to. The above code has landed, making all the students official contributors to Swift. I suggested if there is time, a follow up patch could be provided to migrate to the new namespace and if we land that before the next Swift release there would be no increased backwards compatibility burden. I‚Äôm very pleased to announce that the team picked up this follow up only a few weeks ago, and we are currently working on the namespace account quota migration patch. Account quota meta -> sysmeta migration patch This strictly didn‚Äôt come next by the team, they picked this up only last week. But it‚Äôs related so I‚Äôll talk about it now. The `X-Account-Meta-*` namespace is reserved for users to put whatever metadata they want. There is also an `X-Account-Sysmeta-*` namespace that can only be used internally to the cluster to store system metadata on accounts. When the account quota middleware was created, sysmeta didn‚Äôt. So the middleware used the former. It‚Äôs also prudent to mention that only admins can set account level quotas, not the users themselves. But it means if someone happened to set `X-Account-Meta-Quota-Bytes: ` before adding the account quota middleware. This user defined one would be used. So this patch migrated the old object-bytes and new object-count over to the new location as well as support backwards compatibility for object-bytes. It is currently still in review, but looking great so far. Periodic reaper recon dump showing current progress The account reaper looks for deleted accounts and works through all the accounts containers and objects and makes sure they‚Äôre all deleted. As you can imagine this could take a while. So there was a request to log the progress. This led us to talk about logging, metrics and other ways of getting information out of a distributed system, especially in Swift. Logs are always after the fact, so it would be nice to get more live information. So an operator can see why, say a reaper daemon, is taking so long. Swift has an additional location where it can dump process and state information to disk periodically that can be picked up by the operators via the reconnaissance sub system. So this patch uses that. It adds a watcher thread that on an interval will dump the current state of the reaper letting us know it‚Äôs progress. This led to interesting discussions about python, threading and green threading. I am very impressed with the questions being asked and work here. The earlier patch sets had less of a scope and looked good. The later patchsets are getting even better. Adding more information like the current container‚Äôs being worked from multiple green threads. This hasn‚Äôt landed but is getting much closer. SRE and ops are going to love this addition! Container storage-policy modification operator tool When a container is created the user can pick a storage-policy. This is the policy in which the objects will be stored when put into this container. I.e some replication or EC policy. But currently, this can only be set at creation and after that not changed. As part of the Swift consistency engine we have a special daemon called the reconciler that is used to move objects in the wrong storage-policy to the right one. Currently it‚Äôs used when container replicators find objects for a container in the wrong policy. How this can happen was a great discussion point about eventual consistency and network split-brains. There is a lot of interest in the Swift community to add policy migration. And we have some of the bits and pieces in place, but there is still a lot of work to be done to get this feature fully supported for users. A step on that road is to provide an operator tool, a CLI tool available for Swift operators/SRE to use internally of the cluster, to change the policy of a container on disk and trigger this migration. We spent time discussing policy migration, what it would look like, and how this project could easily keep going. The team here really surprised me, thinking outside the box and taking learning from the account quota patch and thinking about where we want to go with this in the future. They created not only an ops tool but also an admin only API allowing an admin to send a POST to a container and change the storage-policy. Giving operators the ability to trigger from inside or outside the cluster. Further, it gets us closer to having a policy-migration API available to users. Once we‚Äôre ready we can simply remove the admin guard. This has led us into discussions about thinking about possible operator workflows and requirements. This is still in review, but patches like this can take some time to go back and forwards before landing. And might also require a new type of testing they haven‚Äôt played with in Swift. A probe test. Which is a very opinionated testing framework (using a SAIO) that has the ability to actually simulate a situation and probe into the backend/disk to assert the correct behaviour. Container-Sharder concurrency improvements We never quite got to writing code for this one. But we did discuss it a lot. And would involve breaking up a very serial driven daemon into one that would concurrently work through containers on disk. Refactoring out and forking into workers. The sharder daemon was purposely developed to be very serial, as it made it easier to debug and get confidence in.. now it‚Äôs just too slow and it needs to finally be made concurrent. We‚Äôve had discussions on how this could look. How the sharder could divide the work amongst workers. Forking processes vs python eventlet green threads. I mention this, not just because it led to deep and great discussions but also because I‚Äôve been told some of the students are still keen to tackle this project after the summer internship ends. Students I‚Äôd love to go into more detail about the students. They all did really great. And they all impressed me. We mostly talked face to face once a week, so I did get a chance to talk quite a bit. But some were very quiet. Which is ok. But it does make it harder for me to talk about them personally. In hindsight, maybe I should have split them up sooner, so I‚Äôd get to know more about each of them through their code. Because unfortunately we never got a chance to break into the smaller teams like we‚Äôd planned, they all basically work together on all the patches. So I need to talk about them as a whole team, which is one of the reasons I laid out this report the way I did. As a group, they were all very punctual to every meeting, I was impressed with the code they produced. To be honest, I expected a lot more back and forth on patches then we did. But their level of code was much better than I anticipated! Working as a team they minimised code blindness, saw gaps and really produced some great code! Best of all, OpenStack Swift is already a much better product today thanks to their efforts! see all ) - China Mobile‚Äôs Use of the Open Infrastructure Blueprint - October 9, 2024 - Inside Open Infrastructure: October 2024 - October 2, 2024 - - September 19, 2024

author: Mahalia Mayne
title: Less than half of employees have discussed flexible working with managers, despite the right to do so, report finds
text: Fewer than half (44 per cent) of UK workers have discussed flexible working arrangements with their managers, despite having the right to do so, a report has found. According to the survey of 1,200 UK workers, conducted by Phoenix Insights, this figure has increased by five percentage points since February 2024, when 39 per cent reported conversations with their boss about flexible working. The figures come despite the [Employment Relations (Flexible Working Act)](https://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2023/1328/pdfs/uksi_20231328_en.pdf?mc_cid=8ad68b89c0&mc_eid=c8247d5eac), which came into effect on 6 April, allowing employees the right to request flexible working arrangements from day one of employment, as well as the opportunity to make two requests within a 12-month period, an increase from the previous limit of one. [Flexible working more important to most employees than a pay rise ‚Äì People Management poll](https://www.peoplemanagement.co.uk/article/1861233/flexible-working-important-employees-pay-rise-%E2%80%93-people-management-poll) [Employees value flexible working over wellbeing perks, survey finds](https://www.peoplemanagement.co.uk/article/1888030/employees-value-flexible-working-wellbeing-perks-survey-finds) [New flexible working laws: an employer‚Äôs guide](https://www.peoplemanagement.co.uk/article/1856168/new-flexible-working-laws-employers-guide) Clare Kelliher, professor of work and organisation at Cranfield School of Management, told People Management: ‚ÄúThere is plenty of evidence to show that having some degree of choice over their working arrangements is popular with employees, so this is unlikely just to be a lack of interest. ‚ÄúIt may be that there is a lack of awareness of the changes to the law, or that the flexible working arrangement on offer ‚Äì perhaps as outlined in the policy ‚Äì are not well-matched to the type of flexibility that employees are looking for.‚Äù However, she said what would be more concerning was if employees were not initiating discussions because they believe that a request is unlikely to be successful, or because they believe that there is a ‚Äúflexibility stigma‚Äù that may reflect negatively on them, such as being seen to be less committed to their job. Kelliher suggested organisations can make sure managers are proactive in bringing up flexible work arrangements with their teams by making sure they have a thorough understanding of the recent legal changes, and can assist managers in realising the true benefits that come with allowing employees to work flexibly, offering support to help them execute it successfully. The survey also discovered that, when looking specifically at workers by age group, people over the age of 55 were the least likely to say their boss had discussed flexible working before the legal ability to request it was introduced, with only 24 per cent confirming this. In contrast, more than half (54 per cent) of 18-34 year olds said their supervisor had discussed flexible working with them by August 2024, as did 46 per cent of 35-54 year olds. Previous research by the company indicated that choices for flexible working grow increasingly important to employees as they age, with 73 per cent of over 55s prioritising flexible working hours in their workplace, compared to 57 per cent of 18-34 year olds and 60 per cent of 35-54 year olds. A further three quarters (74 per cent) of workers are confident in discussing flexible working arrangements with their manager, up from 67 per cent before the right was legalised. However, just 36 per cent are extremely confident. Sara Thompson, group HR director at Phoenix Group, said it is ‚Äúencouraging‚Äù to see an increase in the visibility of flexible work arrangements since the introduction of the right to request them earlier this year, with more people discussing these options with their managers and feeling comfortable doing so. However, she acknowledged that the impact has not been as "significant as it might have been". ‚ÄúThere are still far too many people who are not having these conversations in their workplaces, particularly among the over 50s age group, and who do not feel comfortable engaging in them, potentially harming their ability to remain and thrive in good work,‚Äù Thompson said. She added: ‚ÄúThe right to request flexible working, although a positive step, is not enough by itself - employers must go further to make sure employees are fully aware of their rights and offer as much flexibility in working arrangements as they can‚Äù. Cath Sermon, head of public engagement and campaigns at Phoenix Insights, said that flexible working can be a "game changer" for employees, allowing them to balance work with care obligations or better manage their physical and mental health, particularly for those over the age of 50. ‚ÄúHowever, we know that making flexible work operate in practice needs planning, trust and good conversation between manager and employees. ‚ÄúThe concept of the eight-hour working day is over 200 years old so now is the time for employers and managers to be more imaginative about how to flex requirements and ensure that the legislative changes make a meaningful difference to their employees,‚Äù she said. As a result, Sermon believes it is "crucial" for employers to do more to equip and support these vital talks, as well as to share best practices from across their business, in order to help "normalise and empower" people to stay at work for longer periods of time. In addition, Lucy Cobb, advice operations manager at BrightHR, said: ‚ÄúEmployers aren‚Äôt strictly required to start conversations about flexible working with their employees. But once an employee makes a request, the employer must consider it according to both the law and The Code of Practice. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really up to the employee if they want to ask for flexible working arrangements. Some companies, though, go the extra mile by promoting flexible working options during recruitment and to current staff.‚Äù However, she added that while business owners don‚Äôt have to bring up flexible working proactively, they can‚Äôt ignore a request once it‚Äôs made. ‚ÄúThere are specific rules they need to follow according to the law and the Code of Practice. Ignoring these requests could land them in legal hot water.‚Äù [Read the CIPD guide to making flexible working a success in your organisation](https://www.cipd.org/en/knowledge/tools/journey-planner/)

author: Lance!
title: Argentina defende invencibilidade hist√≥rica contra o Chile; entenda - Lance!
text: Argentina defende invencibilidade hist√≥rica contra o Chile; entenda Partida acontecer√° no Monumental, em Buenos Aires [Lance!](https://www.lance.com.br/autor/lance-2-2-2) [Argentina](https://www.lance.com.br/copa-do-mundo/argentina) e Chile se enfrentam nesta quinta-feira (5), √†s 21h (hor√°rio de Bras√≠lia), no Monumental de N√∫√±ez, em Buenos Aires (ARG). Ao longo da hist√≥ria, os Hermanos defendem uma hist√≥rica invencibilidade diante dos chilenos. Saiba detalhes! [‚û°Ô∏èClique para assistir no Sportv](https://s.afilio.com.br/?id=667ec565a1f4c10001b639cc) ‚û°Ô∏è [Por que Messi ficou fora da convoca√ß√£o da Argentina nesta Data Fifa?](https://www.lance.com.br/futebol-internacional/por-que-messi-ficou-fora-da-convocacao-da-argentina-nesta-data-fifa.html) ‚û°Ô∏è [Tudo sobre os maiores times e as grandes estrelas do futebol no mundo afora agora no WhatsApp. Siga o nosso canal Lance! Futebol Internacional](https://whatsapp.com/channel/0029VaaOuJF7tkjEHLyEnm21) Em Buenos Aires, os argentinos dominam o confronto. Em 33 jogos, s√£o 26 vit√≥rias e sete empates. A equipe ainda n√£o perdeu para o Chile em casa. No √∫ltimo confronto entre as sele√ß√µes, na Copa Am√©rica desta temporada, vit√≥ria da Argentina por 1 a 0. Os Hermanos, por√©m, n√£o vencem os chilenos em casa desde o 2 a 1 de 2019. Nos √∫ltimos dois encontros, empates por 1 a 1 marcaram a partida. ‚úÖ FICHA T√âCNICA Argentina x Chile 7¬™ rodada - Eliminat√≥rias Sul-Americanas para a Copa do Mundo de 2026 üóìÔ∏è Data e hor√°rio: quinta-feira, 5 de setembro de 2024, √†s 21h (de Bras√≠lia) üìç Local: Monumental de N√∫√±ez, em Buenos Aires (ARG) üì∫ Onde assistir: SporTV e Globoplay üï¥Ô∏è √Årbitro: Jes√∫s Valenzuela-VEN üîç VAR: Juan Soto-VEN ‚öΩ PROV√ÅVEIS ESCALA√á√ïES ARGENTINA (T√©cnico: Lionel Scaloni) Emiliano Mart√≠nez; Nahuel Molina, Cristian Romero, Lisandro Mart√≠nez e Valent√≠n Barco; Rodrigo de Paul, Enzo Fern√°ndez e Alexis Mac Allister; Nico Gonz√°lez, Lautaro Mart√≠nez e Juli√°n √Ålvarez CHILE (T√©cnico: Ricardo Gareca) Gabriel Arias; Mauricio Isla, Benjam√≠n Kuscevic, Guillermo Marip√°n e Eugenio Mena; Marcelino N√∫√±ez, Diego Vald√©s e Rodrigo Echeverr√≠a; Dar√≠o Osorio, Eduardo Vargas e Ben Brereton Diaz Tudo sobre

author: Leonardo Torresi
title: Tres pilotos de Aerol√≠neas Argentinas fueron despedidos por negarse a operar dos aviones que deb√≠an ser devueltos
text: Tres pilotos de Aerol√≠neas Argentinas fueron despedidos por negarse a trasladar dos aviones Embraer 190 que deb√≠a ser devueltos a Lessor (empresa que se dedica al alquiler de aeronaves), aduciendo que no avalar√≠an el vaciamiento de la empresa. La decisi√≥n se concreta en momentos en que la Asociaci√≥n de Pilotos de L√≠neas A√©reas (APLA) se prepara para iniciar a este viernes a las 12 un paro por 24 horas que afectar√° a m√°s de 300 vuelos y perjudicar√° a m√°s de 37 mil pasajeros de la l√≠nea de bandera. Seg√∫n confirmaron a la agenia NA fuentes vinculadas a la compa√±√≠a estatal, la negativa de los pilotos se debi√≥ a una directiva de APLA, liderada por el sindicalista y miembro del Directorio de Aerol√≠neas, Pablo Bir√≥, quien argument√≥ estar en contra del ‚Äúachique‚Äù de la compa√±√≠a. Suscribite Paro de gremios aeron√°uticos para este viernes 13 de septiembre: qu√© aeropuertos afectar√° y cu√°nto durar√° La negativa del traslado le acarrea a Aerol√≠neas una multa alta, del orden de los 26 mil d√≥lares por cada aeronave, m√°s los gastos derivados del incumplimiento de la devoluci√≥n de acuerdo con la finalizaci√≥n del contrato. Calculando el mes de demora de entrega, m√°s los posibles da√±os a reclamar por el Lessor por el retraso, la suma que deber√≠a afrontar Aerol√≠neas ser√≠a de 800 mil d√≥lares. Las fuentes de la empresa descartaron cualquier intenci√≥n de ‚Äúvaciamiento‚Äù de la empresa, porque los dos aviones que se negaron a trasladar iban ‚Äúen devoluci√≥n‚Äù junto a un tercero que est√° en id√©ntica situaci√≥n, pero este a√±o ya ingresaron otros tres, por lo que ‚Äúla flota se mantienen el mismo n√∫mero que el a√±o pasado‚Äù. Mientras tanto, el sindicato de pilotos, analizaba la posibilidad de sumar nuevas medidas de fuerza a la que concretar√°n este viernes. Javier Milei firm√≥ la reglamentaci√≥n que declara la esencialidad del servicio aeron√°utico El presidente Javier Milei firm√≥ este jueves la reglamentaci√≥n del art√≠culo 182 del DNU 70/23, con los lineamientos aplicables a la prestaci√≥n del servicio esencial de aeron√°utica civil comercial . La decisi√≥n fue anunciada por el Ministro de Desregulaci√≥n y Transformaci√≥n del Estado de la Naci√≥n, Federico Sturzenegger a trav√©s de su cuenta de la red social X. "El presidente Javier Milei acaba de firmar la reglamentaci√≥n del art√≠culo 182 del DNU 70/23 con los lineamientos aplicables a la prestaci√≥n del servicio esencial de aeron√°utica civil comercial. Ma√±ana daremos m√°s detalles‚Ä¶", inform√≥ el funcionario. La implementaci√≥n de esta medida hab√≠a sido anunciada tras el paro que llevaron adelante, d√≠as atr√°s, los gremios. La medida provoc√≥ un enorme perjuicio a Aerol√≠neas Argentinas y sus usuarios. LT

author: Zacks Investment Research
title: Lantheus Holdings (LNTH) Exceeds Market Returns: Some Facts to Consider - January 5, 2024 - Zacks.com
text:
In the latest trading session, Lantheus Holdings ( LNTH Quick Quote LNTH - Free Report ) closed at $64.49, marking a +0.25% move from the previous day. The stock's change was more than the S&P 500's daily gain of 0.18%. Elsewhere, the Dow gained 0.07%, while the tech-heavy Nasdaq added 0.1%.
Heading into today, shares of the diagnostic imaging company had lost 6.13% over the past month, lagging the Medical sector's gain of 6.12% and the S&P 500's gain of 2.75% in that time.
The investment community will be closely monitoring the performance of Lantheus Holdings in its forthcoming earnings report. The company's upcoming EPS is projected at $1.36, signifying a 0.73% drop compared to the same quarter of the previous year. Our most recent consensus estimate is calling for quarterly revenue of $326.74 million, up 24.16% from the year-ago period.
It is also important to note the recent changes to analyst estimates for Lantheus Holdings. These revisions help to show the ever-changing nature of near-term business trends. Hence, positive alterations in estimates signify analyst optimism regarding the company's business and profitability.
Our research shows that these estimate changes are directly correlated with near-term stock prices. Investors can capitalize on this by using the Zacks Rank. This model considers these estimate changes and provides a simple, actionable rating system.
Ranging from #1 (Strong Buy) to #5 (Strong Sell), the Zacks Rank system has a proven, outside-audited track record of outperformance, with #1 stocks returning an average of +25% annually since 1988. Within the past 30 days, our consensus EPS projection has moved 0.22% higher. Lantheus Holdings presently features a Zacks Rank of #3 (Hold).
Digging into valuation, Lantheus Holdings currently has a Forward P/E ratio of 10.56. For comparison, its industry has an average Forward P/E of 21.29, which means Lantheus Holdings is trading at a discount to the group.
The Medical - Products industry is part of the Medical sector. With its current Zacks Industry Rank of 185, this industry ranks in the bottom 27% of all industries, numbering over 250.
The Zacks Industry Rank is ordered from best to worst in terms of the average Zacks Rank of the individual companies within each of these sectors. Our research shows that the top 50% rated industries outperform the bottom half by a factor of 2 to 1.
Don't forget to use Zacks.com to keep track of all these stock-moving metrics, and others, in the upcoming trading sessions.
